Issues.Title: a new function to retrieve local source entry  (for debugging)
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

_No response_

### Description

I propose a function that would return from where it was called.
An output alike 'main.ts functionxy r43' where the row number refers to the start of the function or observable or class or ...'  

I think the request is simple, currently there is no way to tell from within a running application to tell where its from.
Sure one can do console.log ('main.ts my function', myMessage)  is a workaround.

However imagine yourself a large application in an angular upgrade.
And each function/method observable etc requires a handwritten line to tell the origin.
. ..Its the way how i currently do it.. and it's cumbersome.

I have created a public [debug library for Angular and RXJS ](https://github.com/PGTBoos/RxJs-Debug.ts)
in which one now might add  identification location string as a possible overload, for a group of debug functions.
But it's not elegant, i have tried to get such info in other ways as well, but none really worked in all cases, and most worked not at all. This information isn't available once the code is compiled, it becomes a java blob.




### Proposed solution

a string function that upon build
keeps track of function names and observable names, and generates a short identification with at least the filename and origin in that file preferably also with a row number of the function.

### Alternatives considered

use a const in every function that you want to log
This may sounds as sure why not.. till you do large application and try to debug rxjs within your app.

### Command

### Is this a regression?

### Description

If the current route is in `/path-some-where`, and the fetch request path is `/path-some-where/media/x-logo.svg`.
the correct path should use baseHref instead of the current path.

```ts
import iconXLogo from "~/assets/icons/x-logo.svg";

console.log({ iconXLogo });

// { iconXLogo: './media/x-logo.svg' }
```

```json
"loader": {

},
```

2. Add the following content to `src/types.d.ts`

```ts
declare module "*.svg" {
  const url: string;
  export default url;
}
```

3. Place a svg icon file to `src/assets/icons/x-logo.svg`
4. import the svg icon and add to `MatIconRegistry`

```ts
matIconRegistry.addSvgIcon("x-logo", domSanitizer.bypassSecurityTrustResourceUrl(iconXLogo));
```

5. use this icon in some where `<mat-icon svgIcon="x-logo"></mat-icon>`

6. run dev server and open in browser

### Command

serve

### Is this a regression?

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

17.3.4

### Description

I'm encountering an issue where ng serve fails to build and serve my Angular application when I use the @import directive in the index.html file. This behavior is unexpected as the @import rule is a standard CSS mechanism.

### Minimal Reproduction

1. Create a new project with `ng new` (using Sass (SCSS))

```
  <style>
    @import url('./styles.css');
  </style>
```
3. Run `ng serve`

Issues.Title: Improve visibility of "Re-optimizing dependencies because lockfile has changed" state
Issues.Body:
### Command

serve

### Description

If you server an app for the first time, and it has a substantial size of libraries, you get this experience

- Building...
- Application bundle generation complete. and browser opens
- Browser shows a blank page for a few seconds, and nothing happens
- After a few seconds, the app loads normally

This is the output:

```
Application bundle generation complete. [8.275 seconds]

Watch mode enabled. Watching for file changes...
NOTE: Raw file sizes do not reflect development server per-request transformations.
Re-optimizing dependencies because lockfile has changed
  ➜  Local:   http://localhost:4200/
  ➜  press h + enter to show help
```

If you don't pay very close attention, you might not see the "Re-optimizing" line. And even if you do, you don't necessarily link it to your page not loading, because it just says something about "re-optimizing", which does not sound like it's a mandatory build step. After all, there already was the output "bundle generation complete".

-> it just looks like your app is broken, and you start opening the devtools to figure out what went wrong.

### Describe the solution you'd like

I think it would be good if `ng serve` stayed in the "Building" phase while dependencies are "optimized" the first time, so that the app immediately loads when it opens in the browser.

Issues.Title: Bundle order causes components to be undefined with `build-angular:application`
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

compiler

### Is this a regression?

Yes

### Description

I have created a circular dependency in my project. (I know it isn't best practice to do so.)

This circular dependency causes the `DefaultDashboardComponent` to be emitted after the `dashboard-modules:DASHBOARD_MODULES` array. Which then causes the component to be undefined in this initial array.

```mermaid
graph TD
  dashboard-modules:DASHBOARD_MODULES --> DefaultDashboardComponent;
  DefaultDashboardComponent --> DashboardEndpointsService;
  DashboardEndpointsService --> dashboard-modules:findDashboardNavByKey;
  dashboard-modules:findDashboardNavByKey --> dashboard-modules:DASHBOARD_MODULES;
```

Using the older `@angular-devkit/build-angular:browser` builder didn't suffer from this problem.
